title: Guiding High-Performance SAT Solvers with Unsat-Core Predictions
abstract: The NeuroSAT neural network architecture was introduced in [37] for predicting properties of propositional formulae. When trained to predict the satisfiability of toy problems, it was shown to find solutions and unsatisfiable cores on its own. However, the authors saw "no obvious path" to using the architecture to improve the state-of-the-art. In this work, we train a simplified NeuroSAT architecture to directly predict the unsatisfiable cores of real problems. We modify several high-performance SAT solvers to periodically replace their variable activity scores with NeuroSAT’s prediction of how likely the variables are to appear in an unsatisfiable core. The modified MiniSat solves 10% more problems on SATCOMP-2018 within the standard 5,000 second timeout than the original does. The modified Glucose solves 11% more problems than the original, while the modified Z3 solves 6% more. The gains are even greater when the training is specialized for a specific distribution of problems; on a benchmark of hard problems from a scheduling domain, the modified Glucose solves 20% more problems than the original does within a one-hour timeout. Our results demonstrate that NeuroSAT can provide effective guidance to high-performance SAT solvers on real problems.
problem_description_natural: The paper addresses the problem of improving the performance of high-performance Boolean satisfiability (SAT) solvers by integrating machine learning predictions about unsatisfiable cores. Specifically, the authors train a neural network (a simplified version of NeuroSAT called NeuroCore) to predict which variables are likely to appear in an unsatisfiable core of a given unsatisfiable CNF formula. These predictions are then used to periodically reset the variable activity scores in Conflict-Driven Clause Learning (CDCL) SAT solvers such as MiniSat, Glucose, and Z3. This hybrid approach—termed 'periodic refocusing'—aims to guide the solver's branching heuristic toward more relevant variables, thereby accelerating the solving process on real-world industrial and competition benchmarks.

constraints: For each clause $j$ with positive literals set $P_j$ and negative literals set $N_j$: $\sum_{i \in P_j} x_i + \sum_{i \in N_j} (1 - x_i) \geq 1$
variables: $x_i$: binary decision variable for Boolean variable $i$, where $x_i = 1$ if true, $x_i = 0$ if false

raw_latex_model: $$\begin{aligned} & \text{Given: Boolean variables } x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_{n_v} \text{ and CNF formula with clauses } C_1, C_2, \ldots, C_{n_c} \\ & \text{where each clause } C_j \text{ is a disjunction of literals.} \\ & \text{Variables: } x_i \in \{0,1\} \quad \forall i = 1, \ldots, n_v \\ & \text{Constraints: For each clause } j, \text{ let } P_j = \{i : x_i \text{ appears positively in } C_j\}, \\ & \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad N_j = \{i : \neg x_i \text{ appears in } C_j\}, \\ & \quad \quad \quad \quad \sum_{i \in P_j} x_i + \sum_{i \in N_j} (1 - x_i) \geq 1 \\ & \text{Objective: Feasibility (no explicit optimization), often represented as } \min 0 \text{ or finding any assignment satisfying constraints.} \end{aligned}$$
algorithm_description: The paper uses a neural network (NeuroCore, a simplified NeuroSAT architecture) trained to predict unsatisfiable cores from SAT problems. This network is integrated into high-performance CDCL SAT solvers (MiniSat, Glucose, Z3) via periodic refocusing: periodically querying NeuroCore on the entire problem (including learned clauses) to reset variable activity scores (EVSIDS) based on predicted core likelihood, guiding branching decisions without replacing the base heuristics.
